arm_group.arm_group_label: LIDC treatment and bioimpedance monitoring of venous ulcers.
arm_group.description: Lower extremity venous ulcers will be treated using periodical LIDC stimulation. Wound healing and edema reduction efforts will be monitored using bioimpedance based monitoring.

brief_summary.textblock:
The research group will choose no more than 10 patients having a lower extremity venous
      ulcer(s), less than 5cm diameter and with an estimated one month time of re-epithelization.
      In this study the investigators will follow and monitor the healing of the wound and
      effectiveness of compression therapy using bioimpedance measurement based method. The
      investigators will also treat the wounds using periodical low intensity direct current
      (LIDC) stimulation therapy.

      Bioimpedance monitoring and wound stimulation functionalities are provided by a purpose
      built wound patch. The patch features a printed 4 x 4 stimulation and impedance measurement
      electrodes array (in contact with wound surface) surrounded by a 4-part dual purpose counter
      and impedance reference electrodes (in contact with the intact skin surrounding the wound
      area).

clinical_study.brief_title: Proof-of-concept Study for Bioimpedance Based Monitoring of Venous Ulcers During Galvanic Stimulation
condition: Patients With Lower Extremity Venous Ulcers

detailed_description.textblock:
Objectives of the study

      Primary: Proof-of-concept study of bioimpedance measurement based method for monitoring of
      chronic wound healing and assessment of efficacy of compression therapy. Gathering
      bioimpedance data from the patients with a lower extremity ulcer of venous etiology over
      their healing process. The investigators will seek methods for processing the collected data
      to find the best correlation with visually observed healing of the wound.

      Secondary: Proof-of-concept study of periodical LIDC wound stimulation. The investigators
      will compare the LIDC enhanced healing outcome with appropriate archived data of previous
      studies performed in TAYS.

      Other: Analysis of the received data and reliability evaluation of the methods. Gathering
      relevant user feedback from medical personnel and patients.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Male or female patients with a chronic wound of venous origin.

          -  Patients have signed consent to participate in the study.

          -  Patient is motivated to follow the instructions given by medical personnel and
             research group.

          -  Age 18 - 80 years.

          -  The general health condition of a patient is good.

          -  Wound is expected to heal significantly during the period of approximately one month.

          -  Wound is located in the calf area, at least 3cm above fibula and there is enough
             space for the wound patch placement.

          -  Diameter of a single wound is no more than 5 cm and wound edges are not steep. If a
             patient has multiple small wounds, the wounds are located within an area of 5 x 5cm.
             Wound(s) are greater than or located in the area of 1 x 1 cm at minimum.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Subject does not approve the informed consent.

          -  Subject is not appropriately motivated to follow M.D.'s instructions of treatment (at
             home).

          -  Participation in another clinical trial that involves an investigational drug or
             device that      would interfere this study.

          -  Patient suffers from cognitive problem such as dementia. Patient with dementia may
             have difficulties to follow the pre- and post-operative instructions.

          -  Wound is not expected to be healed during the time reserved for the measurements
             (circa 1 month).

          -  Patient has active wound infection or increased risk of wound infection.

          -  Skin changes or skin disease which could alter the epidermis of the electrode site
             during the measurement period.

          -  Patient is treated with certain medication (e.g. diuretics, growth hormone therapy)
             or suffers from medical condition that would effect on the body composition or
             hydration status(e.g. inadequate nutrition, diarrhea) or otherwise interfere the
             study (e.g. immunosuppression, diabetes). In this case M.D. will assess the situation
             and decision of the participation is done accordingly.

          -  Patient has cancer or other imminent life threatening disease.

          -  Patient is pregnant.

          -  Subjects with diagnosed heart problems (Biodynamics Corp. 2012).

          -  Subject with any implantable electrical device. Such as pacemaker or implanted
             defibrillator. (Biodynamics Corp. 2012). Patient has other electrically conductive
             implanted material in the body. For example metallic prostheses.

intervention.arm_group_label: LIDC treatment and bioimpedance monitoring of venous ulcers.
intervention.description: Wound is stimulated using LIDC current. Stimulation current magnitude is in micro-ampere range. Stimulation sequence is 1 hour on and 1 hour off for 72 hours or 96 hours.
intervention.intervention_name: Periodical low intensity direct current (LIDC) stimulation of wound.

intervention.arm_group_label: LIDC treatment and bioimpedance monitoring of venous ulcers.
intervention.description: Compression bandage is used for reducing swelling of the limbs.

link.description: Micro-current treatment dressing for chronic wounds

clinical_study.official_title: Proof-of-concept Study for Bioimpedance Based Monitoring of Venous Ulcers During Galvanic Stimulation

other_outcome.description: After the final patient visit, a questionaire will be given to patients and personnel.  Questionaire will provide the research group valuable information for further development of the study method and equipment.

authority: Finland: National Supervisory Authority for Wellfare and Health (Valvira).

primary_outcome.description:
We aim to determine how well bioimpedance measurement based method for monitoring of chronic wound healing and assessment of efficacy of compression therapy comply with the results of conventional wound monitoring methods.
We will measure the impedance of the wound and intact skin from multiple locations using 2-electrode configuration. To obtain this a purpose built electrode array will be placed on the wound, covering also area of intact skin. The electrode array will also be used for determining the interstitial fluid status of the leg by 4-electrode impedance measurement.
primary_outcome.measure: 2-electrode bioimpedance data of wound and intact skin. 4-electrode bioimpedance data related to local interstitial fluid status of affected leg.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

Zhao M, Song B, Pu J, Wada T, Reid B, Tai G, Wang F, Guo A, Walczysko P, Gu Y, Sasaki T, Suzuki A, Forrester JV, Bourne HR, Devreotes PN, McCaig CD, Penninger JM. Electrical signals control wound healing through phosphatidylinositol-3-OH kinase-gamma and PTEN. Nature. 2006 Jul 27;442(7101):457-60.

Blount AL, Foster S, Rapp DA, Wilcox R. The use of bioelectric dressings in skin graft harvest sites: a prospective case series. J Burn Care Res. 2012 May-Jun;33(3):354-7. doi: 10.1097/BCR.0b013e31823356e4.

secondary_outcome.description: We will compare the LIDC enhanced healing outcome with appropriate archived data of previous studies performed in Tampere University Hospital.
secondary_outcome.measure: Low intensity direct current stimulation of wound.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label
